page.title: 12THE DISUSED RAILWAY
page.content: In July 1856{Lewes and Uckfield {Railway Company}opened their line. Twelve years later a small stretch was opened between Lewes and Hamsey so that trains could run from Brighton to Uckfield and beyond without having to interrupt their journey by reversing. In the 1960's British Railways decided to close the line because the viaduct over the River Ouse was unsafe. The line was not making muh profit because more people had cars.{The last train {to run from Lewes to Uckfield was in {February 1969. Running up the Ouse Valley, the disused line enables people to walk through Malling and Hamsey. The remains of the railway can be easily seen eg. the ruins of the viaduct over the Ouse and the junction of the 1856 and 1868 lines north of there.
